comments.comment:
That is the correct URL to POST to and it shouldn't need any parameters. By posting to that URL, you are attempting to "like" whatever object has the ID of "100001545091818_180072978720871".

When it works, it works well. I just tried liking a handful of statuses that I had posted (in a test account) and it worked as expected.

That said, FB isn't allowing you to like whatever 100001545091818_180072978720871 is. The error message should give more details, but there was a bug in the Facebook error handler that prevented proper error handling of the kind of error you received. I'd be curious to see what the stack trace looks like when you try this using the latest snapshot builds. I'm also curious as to what kind of object 100001545091818_180072978720871 refers to. I tried looking it up, but I probably don't have permission to see it.

Given that the like() method works well in those cases where the object is likeable, I don't consider this a bug in the like() method. There are some issues regarding error handling that can be addressed here, however.

The exception from this issue's description is due to a bug in FacebookErrorHandler that was fixed as part of the work in SOCIAL-217. If you attempt the same thing using the latest snapshot build, you should at least get an UncategorizedApiException, although you might also get some other ApiException.

Facebook only allows certain kinds of objects to be "liked" through the Graph API and even then the app must have access to the object being liked. For example, if you want to like a certain photo posted by a friend, you not only need "publish_stream" permission to post the like, but you should also have "friend_photos" permission so that the photo object is visible to the application. I've updated the JavaDocs to reflect this requirement.

Certain other objects can be liked through the Graph API, but only when the application is whitelisted by Facebook. It is possible, for example, to like a fan page, but only if Facebook has expressly granted your application that permission. (It's unclear from Facebook's documentation on how to get whitelisted and it's suspected that it's a very exclusive thing...per this article, limited to the "Causes" application: http://www.insidefacebook.com/2010/10/08/causes-whitelisted-like-pages-2/)

I added some additional error handling around a few known errors with like/unlike, so you will get an OperationNotPermittedException in those cases where you are trying to like something that is not likeable.

The object in the exception (100001545091818_180072978720871) is not visible to me and without knowing what kind of object it is, I can only guess as to why FB wouldn't allow you to like it. However, if you try it again with the latest snapshot build, you should get a better exception and perhaps more insight into why FB rejected your like request. If after retrying this with the latest snapshot builds, you still aren't clear on why it failed, let us know what kind of object you're trying to like and what exception you got and we can try to sort this out.

Regarding #5, I'm surprised it works in the explorer, but not thru FacebookTemplate--under the covers, FacebookTemplate is doing the same kind of request. That, plus the nature of the stack trace you gave (the part saying "No error details from Facebook") makes me think there may be something else going on here, either an environment issue or a dependency issue. Okay, I think I've figured out what's going on. I discovered that when using Spring Social with Spring 3.0.5 and HttpComponents HttpClient isn't in the project, you'll get the error you describe above. It works fine with Spring 3.1.0.M2 and it works fine with Spring 3.0.5 if I add HttpClient to the project.

When you don't have HttpClient, Spring Social falls back to use Spring's SimpleClientHttpRequestFactory, which uses the standard Java facilities for creating requests. It seems that doing that creating a POST request with Spring 3.0.5 and SimpleClientHttpRequestFactory will produce a request without a Content-Length header. Apparently Facebook doesn't like POST requests without a Content-Length header.

Adding anything to the request body (even just a space) results in a Content-Length header being added to the request and will make it work. This will impact not only the like() method, but any other methods that POST with an empty body. I scanned the FB module and discovered that this impacts FriendOperations.createFriendList(), FriendOperations.addToFriendList(), EventOperations.acceptInvitation(), EventOperations.declineInvitation(), and EventOperations.maybeInvitation().

So there are 2 immediate workarounds for you:

  • Upgrade to Spring 3.1.0.M2 : Given that this is a milestone, I understand if that's not an option for you.
  • Add HttpComponents HttpClient to the project

Try out either of these 2 options and let me know if they work for you.

Meanwhile, I'm going to look into fixing this in Spring Social. The obvious workaround is to put something into the request body to force a Content-Length header, but I want to look a bit to see if there is a more elegant option than just shoving filler data into the request.

Also note that some of the changes in Spring 3.1.0 that make this work have been backported to the Spring 3.0.x branch and will be in the Spring 3.0.6 release. I've done some testing of the like() method with a locally-built 3.0.6 build and it works as expected.
